UX Design, Prototyping, Usability Testing, Interviews, Personas, Heuristic Evaluations, Survey Evaluations, Agile Project Management, Sprint Planning, Customer Demos Retrospectives, HTML, CSS 
 
Software

Demonstrated ability to set and achieve ambitious goals, supervise and mentor employees, and develop strategic partnerships. Recognized ability to manage multiple projects with challenging priorities, timelines, and budgets. Proven vendor management employing vendor review, selection, and relationship building. 
 
Engage diverse audiences of all sizes, presenting complex ideas and information, utilizing everything from sophisticated computer presentations to straightforward charts and storytelling. Specialties:Project Management, Producing Results, New Media Communication, Social Media, User Experience and Validation, Working with Multiple Stakeholders, Third Parties and converging timelines and interests. Instructor: New Media Communications Oregon State University February 2010  – Present (5 years 7 months) Corvallis, Oregon Area Appointed Adjunct Faculty teaching social media for New Media Communications Department (NMC399). 
 
•	Created the course curriculum, class website and all related materials. 
•	Taught three classes simultaneously online and live format for College of Liberal Arts. 
•	Advise New Media Communications Advanced Gaming Lab. Responsible for equipment selection lab policy and procedure, documentation and maintenance. 
•	Panel Speaker – Broadcast Education Association (BEA), Teaching Mobile Technology. 
•	Speaker – Oregon State University Athletics, Social Media Life Skills. 
•	Speaker – Hewlett-Packard Company, Serious Gaming. Strategic Project Manager Omedia August 2007  –  March 2012  (4 years 8 months) Portland, Oregon Area Strategic management of projects and key accounts specializing in and related to usability, interaction and visual design of innovative technologies. Manage project scope, budget, schedules, vendors and stakeholder teams across international groups and geographies. 
 
•	Heuristic evaluation of mobile, 2ft and 10ft user interfaces. Identify trends and opportunities for improvement in current and future software / hardware releases. 
•	Partner with Intel’s Ultra Mobile Strategic Marketing and Engineering teams to develop valuable quantitative and qualitative product evaluation methodologies and metrics, benchmarks include: 
•	Internet Value Proposition – Influence the adoption and evolution of the testing methodology and procedure to quantify user experience across competitive hardware and software. 
•	Video playback – Research video formats documented known compatibility issues across competitive devices. Produce videos designed to maximize processor utilization and quantify user experience while viewing on mobile devise.  
•	Browser Technology – Research new technologies and plug-in’s. Analyze data and build reports to assess the relevance of emerging browser technologies and third plug-in’s.  
•	Translate quantitative, qualitative and heuristic data to build high-level presentations and summary reports with recommendations to leadership. 
•	Develop usability studies for gathering user feedback on new/prototype software and hardware. Duties included facilitation, development of the data collection schema and script as well as coordination of the recruiting agency, to gather suitable candidates. 
•	Conduct discovery on new projects; research, gather requirements, locate and assemble physical and digital assets resulting in clear documentation of project scope and goals. Technical Manager - LaSells Stewart Center Oregon State University December 2005  –  June 2007  (1 year 7 months) Corvallis, Oregon Area Managed event and facility operations including equipment, staffing, budgets, schedules and customer satisfaction. Led and managed more than 20 part-time student employees including recruitment, retention, training and performance review.  
 
•	Restructured the operations staffing protocol, reassigned staff and created a compensation incentive program to achieve strategic goals resulting in increased revenue and overall customer satisfaction.  
•	Developed and implemented social media communication tools to track employee schedules.  
•	Managed daily operations and audio and video as well as technical support of public, private and non-profit meetings, presentations and special performances. 
•	Department liaison and key contributor to the first OSU Strategic Diversity Action Plan. Senior Producer Take Two Film and Video, Inc. 2001  –  2005  (4 years) Corvallis, Oregon Area Strategic business operations manager directly responsible for account management of Hewlett-Packard Corvallis Site projects and programs as sole video provider. Managed team of four full-time employees and multiple contractors. 
 
•	Led team that produced Vid-net, an innovative internal socially driven multi-media distribution tool used to archive HP IP content. 
•	Produced multiple analog and digital video projects including new product demonstrations, proof of concept, historical perspective, industrial, informational, interview and internal process documentation videos. 
•	Developed, created and managed a webcast technology product used for internal meetings and presentations. 
•	Designed, procured and maintained technical video production equipment. AVID Composer suite, HD and analog video capture and reproduction facility. Responsible for training and documentation. Summary I've always had a natural curiosity about how people think, behave, and feel. By understanding people’s mental models and how they make sense of the world, it helps identify new opportunities to design something that people would actually find valuable and meaningful.  
 
Ultimately, the decision to choose one product/service over another can partly be attributed to its features. However, there is more to consumer decision making than simply comparing product/services at the feature level. Oftentimes, the most influential factors shaping what and why we buy are our perceptions, goals, and values. For that reason, throughout my career and academic studies I have studied people from a multidisciplinary approach of psychology, economic, user experience, and human factors engineering. Summary Yerika Jimenez is a Ph.D. student in Human Center Computing (HCC) at University of Florida under the supervision of Dr. Christina Gardner-McCune. Her research focuses on Child Computer Interaction, Learning Technologies, Human Centered Design, User Experience and Evaluation, Usability and Computer Science Education. She is interested in developing curriculums and programs that not only expose and engage students (in particular, Latino students) to computer science, but also cultivate their interest in the learning processes.

Find more information at: yerikajimenez.com Experience Graduate Research Assistant University of Florida August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) Distributed Research Experience for Undergraduates (DREU) Research intern in Human-Centered Computing Division at Clemson University May 2013  – Present (2 years 4 months) Clemson, SC Yerika is currently a research intern at Clemson University. She is working on two projects. The first project is WATCH-Workshop of African Americans thinking computationally and historically: Rediscovering and Recreating African American Historical Accounts through Mobile App. This project seeks to investigate how African Americans students’ engagement with technology through mobile apps and visitations to South Carolina’s African American historical sites can promote learning in history education. 
 
The second project is Physical Computing: Video Game and Controller Design. This project seeks 
to understand how students learn to program through design-based projects. The role games play in motivating and connecting to students' interests and helping students to express creativity with computing. The extent to which physical computing increases students' understanding of the programming underlying the functionality of physical devices.
